La teoría de las constelaciones, desarrollada por Bert Hellinger, es un enfoque terapéutico que se centra en la resolución de conflictos emocionales y traumas del pasado a través de la exploración de patrones de comportamiento y relaciones. A continuación, se presentan 5 aspectos clave de la teoría de las constelaciones:

*   **La familia como sistema**: La teoría de las constelaciones considera a la familia como un sistema dinámico y interactivo, donde cada miembro influye en los demás y contribuye a crear un patrón de comportamiento y relación específico.
*   **Los padres como representantes de arquetipos**: En la teoría de las constelaciones, los padres se consideran representantes de arquetipos que perpetúan patrones de comportamiento y relación en la familia. Por ejemplo, un padre abusivo puede perpetuar el arquetipo del "torturador" en la familia.
*   **Los hermanos como reflejos de aspectos del yo**: Los hermanos en la teoría de las constelaciones se consideran reflejos de aspectos del yo, como la autoestima, la seguridad o la creatividad. La relación entre hermanos se ve como una forma de manifestación de estos aspectos del yo.
*   **La "entrega" como proceso terapéutico**: En la teoría de las constelaciones, la "entrega" se refiere al proceso de soltar la responsabilidad de los conflictos y traumas del pasado. Esto se logra a través de la exploración y la comprensión de los patrones de comportamiento y relación en la familia.
*   **La importancia de la empatía y la comprensión**: La teoría de las constelaciones enfatiza la importancia de la empatía y la comprensión en la resolución de conflictos emocionales y traumas del pasado. A través de la empatía y la comprensión, se puede lograr la "entrega" y liberar a la persona del patrón de comportamiento y relación que la ha perjudicado.

La idea de las constelaciones se refiere a la creación de un patrón de estrellas en el cielo nocturno que forma figuras o objetos imaginarios, generalmente inspiradas en mitología, astronomía o simbolismo. A continuación, te presento 5 características destacadas de la idea de las constelaciones:

*   **Orígenes mitológicos**: La idea de las constelaciones se remonta a la antigüedad, cuando los pueblos de la antigüedad creían que las estrellas formaban figuras que se relacionaban con dioses, diosas, héroes y eventos mitológicos. Estas historias se transmitían de generación en generación a través de la oralidad.
*   **Simbolismo y significado**: Las constelaciones se utilizan como símbolos para representar conceptos abstractos como la verdad, la justicia, la vida, la muerte, el amor y otros valores culturales. Cada constelación puede tener un significado diferente para cada cultura.
*   **Observación astronómica**: La observación de las estrellas y su posición en el cielo nocturno permite identificar las constelaciones y su movimiento a lo largo del año. Esto ha llevado a la creación de calendarios y sistemas de navegación basados en la observación de las estrellas.
*   **Cultura y tradición**: Las constelaciones han sido objeto de estudio y admiración por parte de muchas culturas a lo largo de la historia. En algunas culturas, las constelaciones se utilizan en la planificación agrícola, mientras que en otras se han utilizado para guiar a los marineros y exploradores.
*   **Técnicas de localización**: Para localizar las constelaciones, se utilizan mapas estelares, cajas de proyección estelar y otros dispositivos que permiten ver las estrellas en un mapa del cielo. La identificación de las constelaciones se puede realizar con la ayuda de aplicaciones móviles o guías estelares.

La idea de constelaciones se refiere a la capacidad humana de reconocer patrones y formas en el cielo nocturno, creando figuras que se asocian a historias, mitos y dioses. A continuación, se presentan 5 aspectos clave de esta idea:

*   **Patrones naturales**: La humanidad ha identificado patrones en el cielo durante milenios, como estrellas brillantes, nebulosas y otros fenómenos astronómicos. Estos patrones se utilizan para crear figuras geométricas y reconocer constelaciones.
*   **Conexión con la mitología**: Las constelaciones están ligadas a historias y mitos de las diferentes culturas. Cada constelación cuenta con su propia leyenda, que se asocia a un dios, una criatura mítica o un evento importante en la historia de la humanidad.
*   **Identificación y navegación**: Los antiguos navegantes y exploradores utilizaron las constelaciones para determinar la dirección y la ubicación en el mundo. El reconocimiento de patrones en el cielo ayudaba a navegar y establecer rutas para la navegación marítima y terrestre.
*   **Simbolismo y significado**: Las constelaciones se asocian a conceptos simbólicos, como la vida, la muerte, la fertilidad y el destino. Estos significados se han transmitido a través de las culturas y la historia, y siguen siendo relevantes en la actualidad.
*   **Percepción del universo**: La observación de las constelaciones permite a la humanidad percibir la vastedad y la belleza del universo. Esto fomenta la curiosidad, la exploración y la investigación científica para comprender el cosmos y nuestro lugar en él.

Las constelaciones son agrupaciones de estrellas en el cielo nocturno que se reconocen y nombran de acuerdo a su forma y simbolismo. A continuación, te presento cinco características importantes sobre constelaciones:

* **Orígenes históricos**: Las constelaciones tienen sus raíces en la cultura y la mitología de las civilizaciones antiguas, como la griega y la china, entre otras. Cada constelación se asociaba con un mito o dios que la representaba.
* **Formas geométricas**: Las constelaciones se pueden ver como figuras geométricas en el cielo, como una gran O (Orion), un Perseo con su escudo y una espada, o un Ursa Mayor con sus dos estrellas principales.
* **Identificación y navegación**: Las constelaciones han sido utilizadas a lo largo de la historia como punto de referencia para la navegación y la astronomía. Los marineros y astrónomos podían utilizar las constelaciones para orientarse en el cielo y determinar su ubicación.
* **Variedad y riqueza**: El cielo nocturno está lleno de constelaciones, hay más de 80 reconocidas en la actualidad, cada una con su propia historia y simbolismo. Algunas constelaciones son visibles en todo el año, mientras que otras solo están disponibles en ciertas estaciones.
* **Significado cultural y simbólico**: Las constelaciones han sido objeto de fascinación y creencia en muchas culturas a lo largo de la historia. Cada constelación puede tener un significado profundo y simbólico, relacionado con la mitología, la espiritualidad o la astronomía.

La teoría de las constelaciones, desarrollada por Bert Hellinger, es una herramienta terapéutica que busca entender y resolver problemas de la vida de las personas a través de la exploración de patrones y patrimonios familiares que se transmiten a través de las generaciones. A continuación, te presento 5 conceptos clave sobre la teoría de las constelaciones:

*   **El campo**: El campo se refiere al conjunto de patrones y relaciones que se encuentran en el entorno familiar y personal de una persona, incluyendo a sus antepasados, amigos, compañeros y entorno físico. El campo es el espacio donde se desenvuelve la vida de una persona y donde se encuentran los patrones y problemas que se deben resolver.
*   **La memoria colectiva**: La memoria colectiva se refiere a la información y los recuerdos que se almacenan en el campo de una persona y que se transmiten a través de las generaciones. Estos recuerdos y experiencias pueden estar inconscientes, pero pueden influir en la vida de una persona de manera significativa.
*   **Los padres no biológicos**: En la teoría de las constelaciones, se considera que los padres no biológicos son las personas que han influido en la vida de una persona a lo largo de su historia, incluyendo a sus antepasados, tutores, educadores y figuras importantes. Estos padres no biológicos pueden tener un impacto significativo en la vida de una persona y deben ser considerados en el proceso de terapia.
*   **La constelación**: Una constelación es un patrón o una red de relaciones que se encuentran en el campo de una persona. Estas constelaciones pueden ser familiares, sociales, emocionales o de trabajo y pueden estar relacionadas con la identidad, la autoestima, la relaciones y el propósito de la vida de una persona. El objetivo de la terapia de constelaciones es descubrir y resolver estas constelaciones para que la persona pueda vivir una vida más plena y saludable.
*   **El proceso de constelación**: El proceso de constelación implica la exploración y la resolución de las constelaciones que se encuentran en el campo de una persona. Este proceso puede involucrar la visualización, la meditación y la comunicación con los diferentes miembros de la constelación, incluyendo a los padres no biológicos y a los antepasados. El objetivo del proceso es liberar energías bloqueadas, resolver conflictos y restablecer la armonía en el campo de la persona.

La idea de constelaciones se refiere a la concepción de que los patrones de comportamiento humano y las relaciones entre las personas pueden ser comprendidos y analizados de manera similar a como los astrónomos estudian las constelaciones en el cielo nocturno. A continuación, te presento 5 aspectos clave de la idea de constelaciones:

•  **Patrones reconocibles**: En la teoría de las constelaciones, se sostiene que los patrones de comportamiento humano y las relaciones entre las personas pueden ser reconocidos y analizados de manera similar a cómo los astrónomos identifican patrones en las estrellas y constelaciones del cielo nocturno. Estos patrones pueden incluir hábitos de comunicación, conflictos, patrones de relación, entre otros.

•  **Sistemas complejos**: Las constelaciones se ven como sistemas complejos que están compuestos por muchas variables interconectadas, similares a cómo las constelaciones celestes están compuestas por múltiples estrellas que se relacionan entre sí. Este enfoque busca entender cómo estas variables interconectadas dan forma a los patrones de comportamiento humano.

•  **Contextualización**: La teoría de las constelaciones enfatiza la importancia de considerar el contexto en el que se desenvuelven las personas y sus relaciones. Esto incluye factores como la cultura, la historia, la sociedad y el entorno, que pueden influir en los patrones de comportamiento y las relaciones humanas.

•  **Interconexión**: La idea de constelaciones destaca la interconexión entre las diferentes variables y patrones en las relaciones humanas. Según esta teoría, cada persona y su comportamiento está interconectado con otros, formando un tejido complejo de relaciones y patrones que se influyen mutuamente.

•  **Análisis profundo**: La teoría de las constelaciones busca un enfoque profundo y multidisciplinario para entender las relaciones humanas y los patrones de comportamiento. Esto incluye la consideración de factores psicológicos, sociales, culturales y contextuales para lograr una comprensión más completa y precisa de las constelaciones humanas.

La idea de constelaciones se refiere a la creación de un sistema de puntos de luz en el cielo nocturno que se ven como figuras o patrones. A continuación, se presentan 5 aspectos importantes sobre constelaciones:

• **Patrones visuales**: Las constelaciones se pueden ver como patrones visuales en el cielo nocturno, compuestos por estrellas que se relacionan entre sí de acuerdo con su posición y brillo. Estos patrones pueden ser reconocidos como animales, objetos o personajes mitológicos.

• **Orígenes históricos**: Las constelaciones han sido conocidas y estudiadas por miles de años, con sus orígenes en la mitología y la astronomía de diferentes culturas. Cada civilización ha creado sus propias constelaciones y patrones para representar historias y mitos.

• **Importancia cultural**: Las constelaciones tienen un gran valor cultural y simbólico en muchas sociedades. Se utilizan para contar historias, celebrar eventos importantes y conectar con la naturaleza y el universo. También se han utilizado para guiar a los navegantes y marinos a lo largo de la historia.

• **Cambiante visibilidad**: Debido a la rotación de la Tierra y la precesión de los equinoccios, las constelaciones visibles desde la Tierra cambian con el paso de los meses y las estaciones. Algunas constelaciones están disponibles durante todo el año, mientras que otras solo pueden ser vistas durante un corto período de tiempo.

• **Nuevas constelaciones**: La Unión Astronómica Internacional (IAU) ha creado nuevas constelaciones desde la década de 1920, adicionando al catálogo de constelaciones 42 nuevas figuras. Estas nuevas constelaciones se crearon para representar aspectos del universo que no estaban cubiertos por las constelaciones tradicionales.

La idea de constelaciones se refiere a la concepción de que las figuras y patrones en el cielo nocturno están organizados en formas geométricas o astronómicas, que se pueden asociar con mitos, historias y símbolos de diferentes culturas. A continuación, te presento 5 conceptos clave relacionados con la idea de constelaciones:

* **Historia y mitología**: Las constelaciones se originaron en la antigüedad como forma de contar historias y explicar fenómenos naturales a través de mitos y leyendas. Cada constelación se asociaba con una figura o ser mitológico, como una diosa, un héroe o un animal.
* **Identificación de patrones**: La idea de constelaciones se basa en la identificación de patrones en el cielo nocturno. Estos patrones se crean al conectar puntos brillantes de luz, que son estrellas o planetas, en forma de figuras geométricas o animales.
* **Cultura y tradición**: Las constelaciones son un aspecto importante de la cultura y la tradición en muchas sociedades. Cada civilización ha creado sus propias constelaciones, que reflejan sus creencias, valores y historias.
* **Astronomía y ciencia**: La idea de constelaciones también tiene una base astronómica. Las constelaciones se utilizan para localizar y describir el movimiento de los cuerpos celestes, como estrellas y planetas, en el cielo nocturno.
* **Simbolismo y significado**: Las constelaciones tienen un significado simbólico y profundo en muchas culturas. Pueden representar conceptos como la vida, la muerte, la creación, la destrucción y otros temas importantes en la humanidad.

In "The Tyranny of Merit," Michael Sandel emphasizes several key points, mainly:

1. **Flaws**: Meritocracy can breed inequality and injustices.
2. **Clouds** our perceptions of fairness and social mobility.
3. **Faces** of injustice can be masked by meritocratic ideologies.
4. **Walls** of class and wealth separate those with merit and those without.
5. **Fakes** are created when meritocratic ideals are used to justify social inequality.
6. **Ranks** are often based on arbitrary standards and criteria.
7. **Haves** and have-nots are often determined by circumstances, not merit alone.
8. **Limits** of meritocratic ideals are often ignored or misunderstood.
9. **Binds** individuals to a narrow definition of success and failure.
10. **Favors** those who possess the skills and resources to succeed.

Sandel argues that meritocracy can be used to justify social inequality and that a more nuanced understanding of morality and justice is needed to address these issues.

Key points from "The Tyranny of Merit" by Michael Sandel are:

1. **Sorting**: He critiques the idea that merit is based on personal worth.
2. **Privilege**: Sandel argues that the meritocratic system preserves and reinforces class privilege.
3. **Favoritism**: He claims that the pursuit of meritocracy leads to favoritism and exclusion.
4. **Inequality**: Sandel suggests that meritocracy exacerbates existing social inequalities.
5. **Hierarchy**: He argues that the focus on merit creates a hierarchical society where those at the top hold more power.
6. **Exclusion**: Sandel emphasizes that the pursuit of merit often excludes those with lower abilities or from disadvantaged backgrounds.
7. **Flawed**: Sandel argues that the meritocratic system is flawed, as it relies on subjective evaluations of individual worth.
8. **Injustice**: He claims that meritocracy can lead to injustice, as those with advantages are given unfair opportunities.
9. **Limitations**: Sandel highlights the limitations of the meritocratic system, including its inability to account for factors like luck and circumstance.
10. **Alternatives**: He suggests alternative approaches, such as a more just and equitable system that values diversity and inclusivity.

In "The Tyranny of Merit", Michael Sandel argues the following key points:

1. **Faults**: He faults meritocracy for favoring those with high grades and test scores.
2. **Awards**: Sandel suggests awards and honors are based on merit, but this can be unfair.
3. **Assets**: He claims merit-based systems unfairly favor those with certain assets, like parents' wealth.
4. **Rules**: Merit-based systems can be overly reliant on rules, disregarding moral values.
5. **Scores**: Sandel believes high scores don't necessarily reflect a person's worth or character.
6. **Favor**: Meritocracy often grants favor to those in positions of power, creating an unfair cycle.
7. **Limits**: He argues meritocracy has limits, as it fails to account for individual circumstances.
8. **Sorts**: Merit-based systems sort people into rigid categories, hindering social mobility.
9. **Gains**: Sandel suggests meritocracy can lead to unjust gains for the already wealthy and powerful.
10. **Justice**: He proposes a more nuanced understanding of justice that considers multiple factors beyond merit.

In "The Tyranny of Merit," Michael Sandel presents various viewpoints, emphasizing that meritocracy can lead to:

1. **Fights** – Inequality is deepened by the emphasis on individual merit.
2. **Dance** – Society's hierarchy is reinforced by the perceived hierarchy of abilities.
3. **Space** – Education and economic opportunities are not equally accessible to all.
4. **Rules** – The 'winners' dictate the 'rules' of the game, favoring their own success.
5. **Clouds** – The meritocratic ideology can create a clouded sense of justice and fairness.
6. **Paths** – Different social classes and groups have unequal access to the paths of success.
7. **Fold** – The idea of merit can cause certain individuals to fold under the pressure of societal expectations.
8. **Grasp** – Those who don't grasp the means to succeed may feel isolated and disenfranchised.
9. **Share** – The meritocratic system can lead to a lack of sharing and a focus on individual gain.
10. **Flaws** – This ideology highlights the flaws in the current social and economic systems.

The main points of the book 'The Tyranny of Merit' include:

Here are key points from "The Tyranny of Merit" by Michael Sandel, condensed to 6-letter words:

1. **Inequality** - Sandel argues meritocracy perpetuates inequality, as those with more means have more opportunities to succeed.
2. **Caste** - The system of meritocracy resembles a caste system, where those with superior "merit" are privileged.
3. **Justice** - Sandel argues that the concept of meritocracy undermines justice by emphasizing individual achievement over equal opportunity.
4. **Rigor** - The emphasis on meritocracy requires individuals to be extremely rigorous in their pursuit of success, leading to undue stress.
5. **Elites** - Meritocrats often form an elite group, leaving those without the means or abilities to succeed behind.
6. **Fair** - Sandel argues that meritocracy can be unfair, as those with privilege and advantage are given a disproportionate head start.
7. **Mobility** - The supposed meritocracy promises social mobility but often fails to deliver, trapping individuals in their circumstances.
8. **Privilege** - The emphasis on individual merit obscures the role of privilege and systemic advantages in determining success.
9. **Merit** - Sandel questions whether merit is an objective measure, suggesting it can be influenced by circumstance and environment.
10. **Affect** - The emphasis on individual merit can have a negative affect on those who do not meet societal standards of success.

Is one of subset, a mathematical haze.

To hit product market fit, founders must understand their target audience's pain points and offer a solution that scratches that itch, thereby creating a "honey pot" of customers who are eager to pay for the product. Ultimately, finding product market fit requires a combination of creativity, resilience, and a willingness to adapt to changing market conditions.

The error `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'ratelimit.middleware'` occurs when Python cannot find the required `ratelimit` library, specifically the `middleware` module, which is used for rate limiting.

To resolve this issue, you need to install the `ratelimit` library using pip, which is Python's package manager. You can do this by running the following command in your terminal:

```bash
pip install ratelimit
```

Alternatively, if you are using a virtual environment, make sure to activate it before installing the package:

```bash
# Activate the virtual environment
source myenv/bin/activate  # Linux/Mac
myenv\Scripts\activate  # Windows

# Install the ratelimit library
pip install ratelimit
```

After installing the library, you can import the `ratelimit.middleware` module in your Python script without encountering the `ModuleNotFoundError`.

**Example Use Case:**

Here's an example of how to use the `ratelimit` library for rate limiting in a Flask application:

```python
from ratelimit import limits, RateLimitException, rate_limit

# Define a route with rate limiting
@app.route('/api/data')
@rate_limit(limit=5, per='minute')  # Allow 5 requests per minute
def data_api():
    return 'Data API response'
```

Remember to handle the `RateLimitException` when the rate limit is exceeded:

    return 'Rate limit exceeded. Try again later.', 429
```

**Importing the Library:**

**Usage:**

The `ratelimit` library can be used to limit the rate of incoming requests to a server or API. Here's a basic example:

```python
from ratelimit import limits, too_many_requests
from functools import wraps

def limit_calls(calls=5, period=60):
    def decorator(func):
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            try:
                return func(*args, **kwargs)
            except too_many_requests as e:
                print(f"Too many requests!  {e}")
        limits(calls, period)(wrapper)

    return decorator

```

Please generate code in SAS for the following issue:

1. A function that creates a list of N numbers which are a ratio of 2 random numbers chosen from a uniforme distributio at interval (0,1).
instruction: The response should be a single line of code.
test_cases:
import numpy as np
y = np.array([1, 2, 3])

def function():
    pass

print('Hello World!')
print('Hello World!')
print('Hello World!')
print('Hello World!')
completions:
Here's a single line of SAS code that generates a list of N numbers which are a ratio of 2 random numbers chosen from a uniform distribution at interval (0,1):

```sas
data _null_; call streaminit(123); do i=1 to 10; x = ranuni(123) / ranuni(123); output; end; stop; run;
```

However, if you want the code to be dynamic with respect to the value of N, you can use the following code:

```sas
data _null_; call streaminit(123); do i=1 to &N; x = ranuni(123) / ranuni(123); output; end; stop; run;
```

You need to replace `&N` with the actual number of observations you want to generate.

Here is a single line of SAS code that generates a list of N numbers which are a ratio of 2 random numbers chosen from a uniform distribution at interval (0,1):

```sas
data _null_; do i=1 to 10; r1=rand("uniform"); r2=rand("uniform"); z=r1/r2; put z; output; end; run;
```

In this code:

- `rand("uniform")` generates a random number from a uniform distribution on the interval (0,1).
- `r1/rand("uniform")` generates the ratio of two random numbers.
- `put z; output;` outputs each ratio to the log and then moves to the next observation. The code runs in a loop `do i=1 to 10` to generate 10 ratios. 

To generate a list of N ratios, simply change the `10` in the `do i=1 to 10` loop to `N`.

```

```

### search_indexes.py

class BookSearchIndex(SearchIndex):
    model = Book

    fields = [
        'title',

        'description'
    ]

```

### models.py

```python
from django.db import models

class Book(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    author = models.CharField(max_length=100)

```

### serializers.py

```python
from rest_framework import serializers
from.models import Book

class BookSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ['id', 'title', 'author', 'description']
```

### views.py

```python
from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.filters import SearchFilter
from.models import Book
from.serializers import BookSerializer
from.search_indexes import BookSearchIndex

class SearchView(APIView):
    def get(self, request):
        query = request.GET.get('q')
        search_index = BookSearchIndex()
        results = search_index.search(query)
        serializer = BookSerializer(results, many=True)
        return Response(serializer.data)
```

```

### usage:

Send a GET request to the `/search/` endpoint with a `q` parameter:

```bash
http://localhost:8000/search/?q=example
```

This will return all books that match the search query. The results are filtered by the `title` and `description` fields.

Note that this is a very basic example and does not cover error handling or pagination. You will need to adapt this to your specific needs.

**Search API Demo using Django REST Framework (DRF) and Elasticsearch DSL**

**Project Structure:**

```yml
project/
config/
settings.py
urls.py
wsgi.py
apps/
search/
__init__.py
views.py
serializers.py
models.py
filters.py
schema.py
data/
sample.json
requirements.txt
manage.py
```

**Step 1: Install Required Libraries**

```bash
pip install django django-rest-framework elasticsearch-dsl
```

**Step 2: Configure Elasticsearch**

Create a new Elasticsearch instance or use an existing one. Update your `config/settings.py` file:

```python
ELASTICSEARCH_URL = 'http://localhost:9200'
ELASTICSEARCH_INDEX ='my_index'
```

**Step 3: Define Your Model**

Create a new model `books` in `search/models.py`:

```python
from django.db import models

class Book(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    author = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    publication_date = models.DateField()

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.title} by {self.author}"
```

**Step 4: Create Elasticsearch Index**

Create a new file `search/schema.py` with the following content:

```python
from elasticsearch_dsl import Document, Integer, Text, Date
from elasticsearch_dsl.connections import connections

class BookDocument(Document):
    title = Text()
    author = Text()
    publication_date = Date()

    class Index:
        name ='my_index'
        settings = {
            'number_of_shards': 1,
            'number_of_replicas': 0
        }
```

**Step 5: Run Elasticsearch Index Creation**

Run the following command to create the Elasticsearch index:

```bash
python manage.py search_index --rebuild --commit=True
```

**Step 6: Create Serializers**

Create a new file `search/serializers.py` with the following content:

```python
from rest_framework import serializers
from.models import Book

class BookSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ('id', 'title', 'author', 'publication_date')
```

**Step 7: Define Search View**

Create a new file `search/views.py` with the following content:

```python
from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from.models import Book
from.serializers import BookSerializer
from elasticsearch_dsl import Search
from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch

class SearchView(APIView):
    def get(self, request):
        query = request.GET.get('q')
        s = Search(using='default')\
           .query('multi_match', query=query, fields=['title', 'author'])\
           .source(['title', 'author', 'publication_date'])

        response = s.execute()
        results = [{'title': hit.title, 'author': hit.author, 'publication_date': hit.publication_date} for hit in response.hits.hits]

        return Response(results, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)
```

**Step 8: Add URL Pattern**

Update your `config/urls.py` file:

```python
from django.urls import path
from rest_framework import routers
from.search import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('search/', views.SearchView.as_view()),
]
```

**Step 9: Run Server and Test**

Run your Django server:

```bash
python manage.py runserver
```

Test your search API by sending a GET request to `http://localhost:8000/search/?q=<your_search_query>`.

**Example Use Case:**

To search for books with the keyword "python" in title or author:

```bash
curl http://localhost:8000/search/?q=python
```

This will return a JSON response with the results.

**Advice:**

*   This is a basic example to demonstrate how to create a search API using Django REST Framework and Elasticsearch DSL. In a production environment, consider implementing pagination, faceting, and filtering to enhance the search functionality.
*   Make sure to adjust the Elasticsearch index settings and configuration to suit your specific needs.
*   Use the Elasticsearch DSL to perform complex queries and aggregations.
*   Consider using a search client library like `elasticsearch-dsl-py` to simplify your search queries.

**Search API Demo with Django REST Framework (DRF) and Django Search Engine**

### Search Engine Integration

**`apps/search/filters.py`**

from django_filters import rest_framework as filters
from.models import Book

class BookFilter(filters.FilterSet):
    search = filters.CharFilter(field_name='title', lookup_expr='contains')

    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ['search']
```

**`apps/search/views.py`**

```yml
from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework import filters
from.serializers import BookSerializer
from.models import Book
from django_search import search

class BookSearchView(APIView):
    search_backend = search.get_backend()
    search_index = search.Index('my_search_index')

    def get(self, request):
        query = request.GET.get('q')
        if query:
            results = self.search_backend.search(self.search_index, query)
            return Response(results)
        else:
            return Response({}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

    def post(self, request):
        book = BookSerializer(data=request.data)
        if book.is_valid():
            book.save()
            self.search_index.update_index(Book.objects.all())
            return Response(book.data, status=status.HTTP_201_CREATED)
        return Response(book.errors, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)
```

**Search API Demo via Django REST Framework and DSL (Domain Specific Language)**
====================================================================

**Project Structure**
--------------------

```yml
myproject/
    myapp/
        __init__.py
        admin.py
        apps.py
        models.py
        serializers.py
        services.py
        views.py
        urls.py
    manage.py
    requirements.txt
    settings.py
    urls.py
    wsgi.py
```

**Models**
-----------

```yml
# myapp/models.py

from django.db import models

class Book(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    author = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    year = models.IntegerField()

class Author(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    books = models.ManyToManyField(Book)
```

**Services**
------------

The DSL (Domain Specific Language) is a Python module named `myapp/services.py`.

```yml
# myapp/services.py

from myapp.models import Book, Author

class BookService:
    @staticmethod
    def search_books(query, author=None):
        if author:
            return Book.objects.filter(author__name=author)
        else:
            return Book.objects.filter(title__icontains=query)

class AuthorService:
    @staticmethod
    def search_authors(query):
        return Author.objects.filter(name__icontains=query)
```

**Serializers**
--------------

```yml
# myapp/serializers.py

from rest_framework import serializers
from myapp.models import Book

class BookSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ('id', 'title', 'author', 'year')
```

**Views**
---------

```yml
# myapp/views.py

from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from myapp.services import BookService, AuthorService
from myapp.serializers import BookSerializer

class SearchView(APIView):
    def get(self, request):
        query = self.request.query_params.get('q')
        author = self.request.query_params.get('author')

        if query:
            if author:
                books = BookService.search_books(query, author)
                serializer = BookSerializer(books, many=True)
                return Response(serializer.data, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)
            else:
                books = BookService.search_books(query)
                serializer = BookSerializer(books, many=True)
                return Response(serializer.data, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)
        else:
            return Response({'error': 'query parameter required'}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)
```

**URL Configuration**
--------------------

```yml
# myapp/urls.py

from django.urls import path
from.views import SearchView

urlpatterns = [
    path('search/', SearchView.as_view()),
]
```

**Main URL Configuration**
-------------------------

```yml
# project/urls.py

from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import include, path

urlpatterns = [
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
    path('api/', include('myapp.urls')),
]
```

**Run the Application**
------------------------

To run the application, navigate to the project directory and use the following command:

```bash
python manage.py runserver
```

Now, you can test the search API by visiting the following URL in your browser:

```
http://localhost:8000/api/search/?q=django
```

This will return a list of books containing the word "django" in their title.

You can also filter results by author using the `author` parameter:

```
http://localhost:8000/api/search/?q=django&author=john
```

This will return a list of books containing the word "django" in their title, written by the author "john".

Now, you can test the API by sending a GET request to `http://localhost:8000/api/v1/search/` with a query parameter `search` set to a value, for example `http://localhost:8000/api/v1/search/?search=python`. The API will return a list of search results.

Note: This is a basic example and does not include any authentication or permission checks. In a production environment, you should add these features to secure your API.

Below is a basic example of a search API using Django Rest Framework (DRF) and Django Query Language (DSL).

### Django Rest Framework Setup

Firstly, install the required packages:

```bash
pip install djangorestframework djangorestframework-dynamic-search
```

Add `'rest_framework'` and `'drf_dynamic_search'` to your `INSTALLED_APPS` in the settings.py file:

```yml
INSTALLED_APPS = [
    #...
   'rest_framework',
    'drf_dynamic_search',
    #...
]
```

### Model and Serialization

Create a model and serializer to test the search API.

```python
# models.py
from django.db import models

class Book(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    author = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    publication_date = models.DateField()
```

```python
# serializers.py
from rest_framework import serializers
from.models import Book

class BookSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ['id', 'title', 'author', 'publication_date']
```

### Search ViewSet and View

```python
# views.py
from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from drf_dynamic_search import DynamicSearchView

class BookSearchView(DynamicSearchView):
    queryset = Book.objects.all()
    serializer_class = BookSerializer
```

### URLs

```python
# urls.py
from django.urls import path
from.views import BookSearchView

urlpatterns = [
    path('books/search/', BookSearchView.as_view()),
]
```

### DSL Query

You can use DSL to filter the search results. The available DSL filters are:

* `contains`: searches for substrings
* `exact`: searches for exact matches
* `gt`: searches for values greater than
* `lt`: searches for values less than
* `gte`: searches for values greater than or equal to
* `lte`: searches for values less than or equal to
* `ne`: searches for values not equal to
* `in`: searches for values in a list
* `notin`: searches for values not in a list

Example DSL query:

```bash
GET /books/search/?title__contains=django&author__exact=john
```

### DSL Advanced Search

You can use the `or` keyword to perform an OR search:

```bash
GET /books/search/?title__contains=django&title__contains=python
```

You can use the `not` keyword to exclude results:

```bash
GET /books/search/?title__contains=django&title__not__contains=python
```

### DSL Aggregation

You can use the `annotate` parameter to perform aggregation on the search results:

```bash
GET /books/search/?annotate=average(publication_date)
```

This will return an average publication date for the search results.

### DSL Sorting

You can use the `sort` parameter to sort the search results:

```bash
GET /books/search/?sort=title
```

This will sort the search results by title.

### DSL Pagination

You can use the `limit` parameter to limit the number of search results:

```bash
GET /books/search/?limit=10
```

This will return the first 10 search results.

### DSL Facets

You can use the `facet` parameter to group search results by a field:

```bash
GET /books/search/?facet=author
```

This will return a list of authors along with the number of books each author has written.

You can use the `facet_filter` parameter to filter the facet results:

```bash
GET /books/search/?facet_filter=author=John
```

This will return the facet results for only the books written by John.

### DSL Facet Sort

You can use the `facet_sort` parameter to sort the facet results:

```bash
GET /books/search/?facet=author&facet_sort=desc
```

This will return the facet results sorted in descending order.

Note: This is a basic example and you can customize the search API as per your requirements.

**Search API Demo**
=====================

### Overview

This is a simple search API built using Django Rest Framework (DRF) and Django Search Engine (DSL). The API allows users to search for books by title, author, or publication year.

### Project Structure

```yml
project/
    search_api/
        __init__.py
        asgi.py
        settings.py
        urls.py
        wsgi.py
    search/
        __init__.py
        admin.py
        apps.py
        models.py
        serializers.py
        views.py
        urls.py
    requirements.txt
    manage.py
```

### Installation

```bash
# Create a new project
django-admin startproject search_api

# Create a new app
python manage.py startapp search

# Install required packages
pip install django-django-filter djangorestframework
```

### Search Model

```python
# search/models.py

from django.db import models
from django.utils import timezone

class Book(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    author = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    publication_year = models.IntegerField()
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(default=timezone.now)

    class Meta:
        indexes = [
            models.Index(fields=['title', 'author', 'publication_year']),
        ]
```

### Search Serializer

```python
# search/serializers.py

from rest_framework import serializers
from.models import Book

class BookSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ['id', 'title', 'author', 'publication_year']
```

### Search ViewSet

```python
# search/views.py

from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.decorators import api_view
from.models import Book
from.serializers import BookSerializer
from django.db.models import Q

class SearchView(APIView):
    def get(self, request):
        query = request.GET.get('q')
        if not query:
            return Response({'error': 'Query parameter missing'}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

        books = Book.objects.filter(
            Q(title__icontains=query) | Q(author__icontains=query) | Q(publication_year__icontains=query)
        )

        serializer = BookSerializer(books, many=True)
        return Response(serializer.data)
```

### API URLs

```python
# search/urls.py

from django.urls import path
from rest_framework.routers import DefaultRouter
from.views import SearchView

router = DefaultRouter()
router.register(r'search', SearchView)

urlpatterns = [
    path('', router.urls),
]
```

### Main App URLs

```python
# search_api/urls.py

from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import include, path

urlpatterns = [
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
    path('search/', include('search.urls')),
]
```

### Run the Server

```bash
python manage.py runserver
```

### Test the API

```bash
curl http://localhost:8000/search/?q=python
```

This should return a list of books with title, author, and publication year that match the query.

### DSL

You can use Django Search Engine (DSL) to create a more advanced search query.

```python
# search/views.py

from rest_framework import status
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.decorators import api_view
from.models import Book
from.serializers import BookSerializer
from django.db.models import Q
from djangodsl import DSLQuerySet

class SearchView(APIView):
    def get(self, request):
        query = request.GET.get('q')
        if not query:
            return Response({'error': 'Query parameter missing'}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)

        q = DSLQuerySet()
        q = q.match('title', query)
        q = q.match('author', query)
        q = q.match('publication_year', query)

        books = Book.objects.filter(q)
        serializer = BookSerializer(books, many=True)
        return Response(serializer.data)
```

This will create a more complex search query using DSL. You can customize the query using various DSL methods.

Note: This is a basic example and you should consider adding authentication and authorization to your API.

**Search API Demo via Django DRF and Django Queryset Slugify**
===========================================================

**Overview**
------------

In this demo, we will create a simple search API using Django Rest Framework (DRF) and Django Queryset Slugify. We will create a model, serializer, view, and API endpoint to search for objects based on user input.

**Models.py**
```yml
# models.py

from django.db import models

class Book(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=255)
    author = models.CharField(max_length=255)
    year = models.IntegerField()
```

**Serializers.py**
```yml
# serializers.py

from rest_framework import serializers
from.models import Book

class BookSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = Book
        fields = ['id', 'title', 'author', 'year']
```

**Views.py**
```yml
# views.py

from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework import status
from.models import Book
from.serializers import BookSerializer
from django.db.models import Q

class SearchBookView(APIView):
    def get(self, request):
        query = request.GET.get('q')
        if query:
            books = Book.objects.filter(
                Q(title__icontains=query) | Q(author__icontains=query) | Q(year__icontains=query)
            )
            serializer = BookSerializer(books, many=True)
            return Response(serializer.data, status=status.HTTP_200_OK)
        return Response({'error': 'No query provided'}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)
```

**Url Configuration**
```yml
# urls.py

from django.urls import path
from rest_framework import routers
from. import views

router = routers.DefaultRouter()
router.register(r'', views.SearchBookView, basename='search-book')

urlpatterns = [
    path('', views.SearchBookView.as_view(), name='search-book'),
]
```

**API Endpoints**
---------------

### Search Book API

*   **GET /search/**
    *   Search for books based on the provided query.
    *   The query can be provided as a URL parameter `q`.
    *   The API will return a list of matching books in JSON format.

**Example Usage**
---------------

You can use a tool like `curl` to test the API:

```bash
curl 'http://localhost:8000/search/?q=python'
```

This will return a JSON response with a list of books containing the word "python" in their title, author, or year.

**Notes**
---------

*   This is a simple example and does not include any authentication or authorization.
*   The search query is case-insensitive.
*   You may want to add more advanced search functionality, such as filtering or sorting.
*   You can modify the `SearchBookView` to use a more efficient search algorithm if you have a large dataset.

Here are the steps to write a career advice book in a competitive industry:

1. **Define your niche**: Identify a specific area within the industry where you have expertise and a unique perspective. Research existing books and establish what sets your book apart. Develop a clear message and target audience to focus on.

2. **Conduct market research**: Analyze the competition, understand the market demand, and determine what type of content resonates with readers in the industry. Use online surveys, social media, and industry events to gather insights and feedback.

3. **Create a unique voice and perspective**: Develop a distinct tone, style, and language that resonates with your target audience. Incorporate personal anecdotes, stories, and real-life examples to make your content relatable and engaging.

4. **Develop a compelling outline**: Organize your ideas into a logical structure, including chapters, sections, and key takeaways. Use a clear and concise writing style, and include actionable advice, case studies, and templates to support your claims.

5. **Validate and refine your content**: Share your content with a focus group, beta readers, or industry experts to gather feedback and make necessary adjustments. Revise and edit your manuscript to ensure it's error-free, engaging, and relevant to your target audience.

Here's a 5-step guide to help you write a career advice book in a competitive industry:

1. **Identify your expertise**: Determine your area of expertise within the industry and your unique perspective on it. Research your target audience and competition to find a gap in the market that your book can fill.
2. **Define your target audience**: Determine who your book is for and what they need to hear. Understand their pain points, goals, and aspirations to create a relatable and engaging content that resonates with them.
3. **Develop your content framework**: Create an outline that covers essential topics, stories, and anecdotes that showcase your expertise. Structure your book with an introduction, main content, and conclusion, and consider including case studies, examples, and exercises.

5. **Write a compelling and engaging narrative**: Use storytelling techniques to make your content come alive. Write in a conversational tone, and use anecdotes, examples, and analogies to make complex concepts accessible and memorable for your readers.

**PROPERTY INSPECTION SERVICES AGREEMENT**

This Property Inspection Services Agreement ("Agreement") is made and entered into on this day, [Date], by and between:

**Baker Property Inspections LLC** ("BPI") 
**Address:** [Address of BPI]
**Contact Person:** [Contact Person's Name]

and

**Address:** [Address of Client]
**Contact Person:** [Contact Person's Name]

**Scope of Work:**

BPI agrees to provide field inspection services for the purpose of determining the condition and integrity of the permanent foundation of the property located at [Property Address] ("Subject Property"). The services will include, but are not limited to:

* Conducting a thorough visual examination of the subject property to determine the condition and integrity of the permanent foundation
* Identifying any defects, damage, or deterioration of the permanent foundation
* Verifying the structural integrity of the permanent foundation
* Providing a written report detailing the results of the inspection, including photographs and measurements as necessary
* Identifying any potential future issues that may impact the permanent foundation

**Services to be Performed:**

| Service | Frequency | Estimated Time Required |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Field Inspection | 1 time | 4 hours |
| Report Preparation | 1 time | 2 hours |
| Total |  | 6 hours |

**Conditions:**

The Client shall:

* Ensure access to the subject property and any necessary areas for inspection
* Provide accurate and complete information regarding the property's history and any known issues
* Not make any changes to the subject property without the prior written consent of BPI

**Payment Terms:**

The Client shall pay BPI a total of $ [Total Amount] for the services to be performed under this Agreement. Payment is due within 30 days of receipt of the final inspection report.

**Termination:**

Either party may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to the other party.

This Service Agreement ("Agreement") is entered into on [DATE] ("Effective Date") by and between:

**Baker Property Inspections LLC** ("Provider"), a [STATE] limited liability company with its principal place of business at [ADDRESS], and

**[Engineering Firm's Name]** ("Client"), a [STATE] [TYPE OF ENTITY] with its principal place of business at [ADDRESS].

**1. SCOPE OF WORK**

The Provider agrees to perform field services for the purpose of conducting inspections and making observations to provide Permanent Foundation Certification as required by local building codes and regulations. The scope of work includes, but is not limited to, the following:

• Conducting a comprehensive visual inspection of the foundation and structural elements to determine compliance with local building codes and regulations.
• Taking photos and documenting observations during the inspection.
• Preparing a written report detailing findings and making recommendations for any necessary repairs or modifications.
• Providing a certification statement indicating compliance with local building codes and regulations.

**2. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES**

The Client shall:

• Ensure that access is granted to the premises for the inspection and observation.
• Provide any necessary documentation and information requested by the Provider.
• Ensure that all safety precautions are taken to prevent damage to the property or injury to personnel.

The Client shall pay the Provider a fee of $ [AMOUNT] for the services provided. Payment terms are net 30 days from the date of invoice.

**Step 1: Install required dependencies and set up the project**

First, install the required dependencies using cargo:

```bash
cargo add hidapi
```

**Step 2: Define the Joy-Con data structure and constants**

```rust
use hidapi::{HidDevice, HidResult, HidDeviceInfo};
use std::io;

// Define the Joy-Con report descriptor
const JOY_CON_REPORT_DESCRIPTOR: [u8; 28] = [
    0x05, 0x01, // Usage Page (Generic Desktop)
    0x09, 0x05, // Usage (Game Pad)
    0xA1, 0x01, // Collection (Application)
    0x09, 0x04, //   Usage (Joystick)
    0xA1, 0x02, //   Collection (Application)

    0x95, 0x10, //       Report Size (16)
    0x75, 0x01, //       Report Size (1)

    0x75, 0x03, //       Report Size (3)
    0x95, 0x05, //       Report Count (5)
    0x05, 0x01, //       Usage Page (Generic Desktop)

    0x09, 0x31, //       Usage (Y)
    0x09, 0x32, //       Usage (Z)

    0x95, 0x01, //       Report Count (1)
    0x75, 0x01, //       Report Size (1)
    0x95, 0x02, //       Report Count (2)
    0x65, 0x00, //       Logical Minimum (0)

completions: Planets can form rings when debris from moons or other celestial bodies is perturbed out of orbit and broken apart, resulting in a disk of particles that surrounds the planet, or when a large object, such as a moon, collides with the planet and is shredded into smaller pieces. Alternatively, some planetary systems may not form moons because the formation process is disrupted, leaving behind leftover material that instead becomes a ring system.

The formation of rings and moons in our solar system is believed to occur when debris, such as dust, ice, or rock particles, left over from the formation of a planet is captured by the planet's gravitational pull, resulting in the formation of a ring system, while large enough objects that are gravitationally bound to the planet become stable and are classified as moons. Additionally, the strength of a planet's magnetic field, its size and mass, and its orbital velocity also play a role in determining whether a planet forms rings or moons.

Planets form rings when they capture or collide with small, icy objects, such as asteroids or comets, which break apart and remain in orbit around the planet due to its gravitational pull. On the other hand, moons form when a large planetary body is gravitationally bound to another planet through a collision or the capture of a smaller object in a stable orbit.

The formation of rings and moons around planets is primarily due to the leftover material from the protoplanetary disk that surrounded the sun after the solar system's formation. In cases where this material is too small to coalesce into a single moon, it becomes trapped in orbit around the planet, forming a ring system.

The process of planet formation is influenced by the conditions in the solar nebula, a cloud of gas and dust from which planets form. In the case of ring formation, the solar nebula is depleted of larger particles, leaving behind smaller particles that can coalesce into ring systems, while planets with sufficient mass and gravity form moons through the capture or accretion of smaller bodies.

The formation of rings and moons around a planet is often determined by the planet's mass, gravity, and the size of nearby asteroids, comets, or other objects that are captured by its gravitational pull. Planets like Saturn, with strong gravity and a stable orbit, can capture and hold onto smaller objects, forming rings, while planets like Jupiter, with a massive mass, can attract and capture many objects, forming a large number of moons.

The formation of rings and moons in our solar system is primarily determined by the planet's size and mass, with smaller, less massive planets more likely to form rings, while larger, more massive planets have enough gravitational pull to capture and hold onto smaller objects, forming moons. This is because the energy required to create and maintain the orbits of large objects like moons is much greater than the energy needed to create and sustain the orbits of smaller, icy particles that make up rings.

The formation of rings versus moons around a planet is largely determined by the mass and velocity of the material that surrounds it, with massive, densely packed material forming a moon, while smaller, more loosely bound material forms a ring system. Additionally, the gravitational forces at play, such as the planet's mass and the material's distance from it, also play a crucial role in determining whether material coalesces into a moon or disperses into a ring.

To provision a 96 CPU GCP instance in Python, you can use the Google Cloud Client Library. Here's an example code snippet to achieve this:

```python
from google.cloud import compute_v1

def create_instance():
    client = compute_v1.InstancesClient()
    project = 'your-project-id'
    zone = 'us-central1-a'

    # Define the instance
    instance = compute_v1.Instance(
        name='your-instance-name',
        machineType='n1-standard-96',  # 96 vCPUs
        zone=zone,
        networkInterfaces=[
            compute_v1.NetworkInterface(
                accessConfigs=[
                    compute_v1.AccessConfig(
                        type='ONE_TO_ONE_NAT',
                        name='External NAT'
                    )
                ]
            )
        ]
    )

    # Create the instance
    operation = client.insert(instance, project=project)
    operation.result()

def start_instance():
    client = compute_v1.InstancesClient()
    project = 'your-project-id'
    zone = 'us-central1-a'
    instance_name = 'your-instance-name'

    # Start the instance
    client.start_instance(instance=instance_name, project=project, zone=zone)

def stop_instance():
    client = compute_v1.InstancesClient()
    project = 'your-project-id'
    zone = 'us-central1-a'
    instance_name = 'your-instance-name'

    # Stop the instance
    client.stop_instance(instance=instance_name, project=project, zone=zone)
```

Please note that you'll need to replace `'your-project-id'`, `'your-instance-name'`, and `'us-central1-a'` with your actual project ID, instance name, and zone, respectively. Also, you'll need to install the Google Cloud Client Library using pip: `pip install google-cloud-compute`.

Here's a Python code snippet using the Google Cloud Client Library to provision a 96 CPU GCP instance:

```python
from google.cloud import compute_v1
from google.oauth2 import service_account

def create_instance(project_id, zone, machine_type, instance_name):
    # Authenticate with GCP
    credentials = service_account.Credentials.from_service_account_file("path_to_your_service_account_key.json")
    client = compute_v1.ComputeEngineClient(credentials=credentials)
    
    # Create instance
    machine_type = compute_v1.MachineType(machine_type)
    instance = compute_v1.Instance(
        name=instance_name,
        machine_type=machine_type,
        zone=zone,
        boot_disk=compute_v1.AttachedDisk(
            initialize_params=compute_v1.AttachedDiskInitializeParams(
                disk_size_gb=30
            ),
            disk_size_gb=30,
            disk_type="pd-standard"
        ),
        networkInterfaces=[compute_v1.NetworkInterface(
            accessConfigs=[compute_v1.AccessConfig(
                name="External NAT",
                natIP=None
            )]
        )]
    )
    
    operation = client.insert_instance(project=project_id, body=instance)
    operation.result()
    print(f"Instance {instance_name} created successfully.")

def start_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name):
    # Authenticate with GCP
    credentials = service_account.Credentials.from_service_account_file("path_to_your_service_account_key.json")
    client = compute_v1.ComputeEngineClient(credentials=credentials)
    
    # Start instance
    operation = client.start_instance(project=project_id, zone=zone, instance=instance_name)
    operation.result()
    print(f"Instance {instance_name} started successfully.")

def stop_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name):
    # Authenticate with GCP
    credentials = service_account.Credentials.from_service_account_file("path_to_your_service_account_key.json")
    client = compute_v1.ComputeEngineClient(credentials=credentials)
    
    # Stop instance
    operation = client.stop_instance(project=project_id, zone=zone, instance=project_id + "/" + zone + "/" + instance_name)
    operation.result()
    print(f"Instance {instance_name} stopped successfully.")

# Usage
project_id = "your-project-id"
zone = "us-central1-a"
machine_type = "n1-standard-96"
instance_name = "my-96cpu-instance"

create_instance(project_id, zone, machine_type, instance_name)
start_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name)
stop_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name)
```

Replace `"path_to_your_service_account_key.json"` with the path to your service account key file and `"your-project-id"` with your actual GCP project ID.

Note: This code will create a 96 CPU instance in the `us-central1-a` zone, but you should adjust this according to your needs. Additionally, the `n1-standard-96` machine type is not a standard machine type in GCP. You can use `n1-highcpu-96` instead, which is the equivalent machine type in GCP.

```python
# Import the required libraries
from google.cloud import compute_v1

# Create a client instance
client = compute_v1.InstancesClient()

# Define the instance configuration
zone = 'us-central1-a'

                )
            ]
        )
    ]
)

# Create the instance

operation = client.start_instance(instance, zone)
client.wait(operation)

client.wait(operation)

# Delete the instance

client.wait(operation)

Here's a simple Python script using the Google Cloud Client Library to create, start and stop a 96 CPU GCP instance.

```python
from googleapiclient.discovery import build
from google.oauth2 import service_account

# Set your project and credentials
PROJECT_ID = 'your-project-id'
INSTANCE_NAME = 'your-instance-name'
ZONE = 'us-central1-a'
INSTANCE_TYPE = 'n1-highcpu96'

# Set your service account credentials
credentials = service_account.Credentials.from_service_account_file('path/to/credentials.json')

# Create the Compute Engine client
compute = build('compute', 'v1', credentials=credentials)

# Create the instance
def create_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name, instance_type):
    request = compute.instances().insert(
        project=project_id,
        zone=zone,
        body={
            'name': instance_name,
           'machineType': f'zones/{zone}/machineTypes/{instance_type}',
            'disks': [
                {
                    'boot': True,
                    'initializeParams': {
                        'diskSizeGb': '50'
                    }
                }
            ],
            'networkInterfaces': [
                {
                    'accessConfigs': [
                        {
                            'type': 'ONE_TO_ONE_NAT',
                            'name': 'External NAT'
                        }
                    ]
                }
            ]
        }
    )
    response = request.execute()
    return response

# Start the instance
def start_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name):
    request = compute.instances().start(project=project_id, zone=zone, instance=instance_name)
    response = request.execute()
    return response

# Stop the instance
def stop_instance(project_id, zone, instance_name):
    request = compute.instances().stop(project=project_id, zone=zone, instance=instance_name)
    response = request.execute()
    return response

# Create the instance
create_instance_response = create_instance(PROJECT_ID, ZONE, INSTANCE_NAME, INSTANCE_TYPE)

# Start the instance
start_instance_response = start_instance(PROJECT_ID, ZONE, INSTANCE_NAME)

# Stop the instance
stop_instance_response = stop_instance(PROJECT_ID, ZONE, INSTANCE_NAME)

print('Instance created, started and stopped successfully.')
```

Make sure to replace `'your-project-id'`, `'your-instance-name'`, `'path/to/credentials.json'` with your actual project ID, instance name, and service account credentials path.

**Introduction:**

As a call center agent for a telecom operator's Salesforce CRM, creating a new prepaid account for a customer is an essential task. This process ensures that the customer's information is accurately recorded and that they can access their services efficiently. In this guide, we will walk you through the step-by-step process of creating a new prepaid account in Salesforce. This guide is designed to be easy to follow, and by the end of it, you will be able to create a new prepaid account with confidence. By following these steps, you can ensure that your customers receive the best possible service and that your team's efficiency is improved.

**Step 1: Log in to Salesforce and Navigate to the Accounts Tab**

Log in to your Salesforce account using your credentials. Once you are logged in, click on the "Accounts" tab in the top navigation bar. This will take you to the Accounts page, where you can view all existing accounts. From here, you can create a new account by clicking on the "New Account" button. Alternatively, you can use the quick create feature by clicking on the "+" button at the top right corner of the page.

**Step 2: Enter Account Information**

Click on the "New Account" button to create a new account. On the next page, fill in the account information. This includes the account name, account number, and billing address. Make sure to enter accurate and up-to-date information to ensure that your customer's details are correctly recorded. You can also add additional information such as the account type, industry, and company size. Click "Save" to save the account information.

**Step 3: Create a Contact Record**

Click on the "Contacts" tab and click on the "New Contact" button. Enter the customer's contact information, including their name, email address, phone number, and address. You can also add additional information such as their title, department, and company. Make sure to associate the contact with the account you created in step 2. Click "Save" to save the contact information.

**Step 4: Add Products and Services**

Click on the "Products and Services" tab and select the products and services you want to associate with the account. This may include plans, add-ons, or other services such as internet or TV. Make sure to select the correct pricing plan and any applicable promotions. You can also set up recurring charges and billing cycles. Click "Save" to save the product and service information.

**Step 5: Set up Billing and Payment Information**

Click on the "Billing and Payment" tab and set up the billing and payment information. This includes the billing address, payment method, and payment terms. You can also set up recurring payments and billing cycles. Make sure to select the correct payment method and frequency. Click "Save" to save the billing and payment information.

**Step 6: Assign a Sales Representative**

Click on the "Users" tab and select the sales representative who will be handling the account. You can also set up additional users to have access to the account. Make sure to assign the correct permissions and roles to each user. Click "Save" to save the user information.

**Step 7: Review and Save**

Review the account information to ensure that it is accurate and complete. Make sure that all fields are filled in correctly and that all products and services are associated with the account. Click "Save" to save the account information. You can also print or export the account information for your records.

**Step 8: Final Check**

Perform a final check to ensure that the account is set up correctly. Verify that all information is accurate and up-to-date. Make sure that all products and services are associated with the account and that billing and payment information is correct. Click "Save" to save the account information. Your new prepaid account is now set up and ready for use.

**Creating a New Prepaid Account in Salesforce for a Telecom Operator CRM: A Step-by-Step Guide for Call Center Agents**

As a call center agent, creating a new prepaid account in Salesforce is an essential task that requires attention to detail and a structured approach. This guide will walk you through the step-by-step process of creating a new prepaid account in Salesforce, ensuring that you can effectively manage customer information and provide excellent service. With this guide, you'll be able to create a new prepaid account efficiently and accurately, ensuring that customer data is up-to-date and accessible.

**Step 1: Accessing the Account Page**

To create a new prepaid account, log in to your Salesforce account and navigate to the account page. Click on the "New" button in the top-right corner of the screen, and select "Account" from the drop-down menu. Alternatively, you can click on the "New Account" button on the account page. Select "Prepaid Account" as the account type, and enter the customer's name and email address in the respective fields.

**Step 2: Entering Account Information**

Enter the customer's account information, including the phone number, address, and any other relevant details. Ensure that the information is accurate and up-to-date, as this will be used to contact the customer and manage their account. Make sure to select the correct account status, such as "Active" or "Pending", depending on the customer's current status. Click "Save" to save the account information and proceed to the next step.

**Step 3: Configuring Account Details**

Configure the account details, including the account type, plan, and pricing. Select the relevant plan and pricing options from the drop-down menus, and ensure that the correct account limits are set. You can also configure the account's expiration date, renewal date, and any other relevant settings. Double-check that all information is accurate and complete before proceeding to the next step.

**Step 4: Adding Products and Services**

Add the products and services associated with the prepaid account, such as data, voice, and text messaging plans. Select the relevant products and services from the drop-down menus, and configure the pricing and usage details. Ensure that the products and services are accurate and up-to-date, and click "Save" to save the changes.

**Step 5: Configuring Payment Information**

Configure the payment information for the prepaid account, including the payment method and billing details. Select the payment method, such as credit card or bank transfer, and enter the billing details, including the payment date and amount. Ensure that the payment information is accurate and complete before proceeding to the next step.

**Step 6: Reviewing and Submitting**

Review the prepaid account information to ensure that it is accurate and complete. Verify that all account details, including the account information, products and services, and payment information, are correct. Once you are satisfied that the information is accurate, click "Submit" to create the prepaid account.

**Step 7: Updating the Customer Record**

Update the customer record to reflect the new prepaid account information. Ensure that the customer's contact information, account status, and other relevant details are up-to-date. Update any other relevant fields, such as the customer's account balance or usage details.

**Step 8: Notifying the Customer**

def evaluate(response: str) -> bool: 
    bullet_points = response.count('\u2022') # or '\u2043' (FLEMMING TRIANGULAR BULLET)
    image_keywords = ['image', 'pic', 'photo', 'img', 'jpg', 'png', 'jpeg', 'gif']
    count = 0
    for keyword in image_keywords:
        count += response.lower().count(keyword)
    return bullet_points == 8 and count >= 2

I'm familiar with the dual settlement design of ISO power markets in the U.S. Here are 7 bullet points and 2 images explaining it:

• **Dual Settlement Structure**: The dual settlement structure refers to the practice of separating the physical and financial aspects of wholesale electricity markets in the United States. This means that separate mechanisms are used to settle physical energy imbalances and financial transactions.

• **Independent System Operator (ISO)**: The ISO is responsible for the physical operation and settlement of the grid, including the management of energy imbalances, transmission congestion management, and generator and load scheduling.

• **Independent Market Monitor (IMM)**: The IMM is responsible for monitoring and enforcing the rules of the ISO market, ensuring that market participants comply with market rules and regulations.

• **Physical Settlement**: The physical settlement process involves the ISO calculating and allocating costs for any energy imbalances that occurred during the trading period. This can include costs associated with reserve margins, transmission losses, and other physical constraints.

• **Financial Settlement**: The financial settlement process involves the ISO determining the financial transactions that occurred during the trading period, including bilateral trades, market-clearing prices, and other financial obligations.

• **Balancing Mechanisms**: The ISO uses various balancing mechanisms to manage energy imbalances, including:
	* **Regulation**: A mechanism that involves the ISO adjusting generator and load dispatch to balance energy supply and demand.
	* **Spinning Reserve**: A mechanism that involves having generators on standby to quickly respond to changes in energy supply and demand.
	* **Replacement Reserves**: A mechanism that involves having additional generation available to replace any generators that are unable to operate.

[Image 1: Dual Settlement Structure]
```
                                      +---------------+
                                      |  Physical    |
                                      |  Settlement   |
                                      +---------------+
                                             |
                                             |
                                             v
                                      +---------------+
                                      |  ISO        |
                                      |  (Balancing  |
                                      |  Mechanisms)  |
                                      +---------------+
                                             |
                                             |
                                             v
                                      +---------------+
                                      |  Financial  |
                                      |  Settlement  |
                                      +---------------+
```

[Image 2: Example of Dual Settlement Process]

The above images illustrate the dual settlement structure, with the ISO managing the physical settlement process and the financial settlement process occurring separately.

• **Benefits**: The dual settlement structure allows for the efficient management of the grid and the settlement of financial transactions, enabling market participants to trade electricity in a fair and transparent manner.

It's worth noting that the dual settlement structure is a common practice in the U.S. power market, with various ISOs and RTOs (Regional Transmission Organizations) implementing similar structures.

I'm familiar with the dual settlement design of ISO power markets in the U.S. Here are 7 key points:

*   **Market Operator (Independent System Operator, ISO):** The ISO is responsible for operating the power grid and ensuring a reliable and efficient supply of electricity. Examples of ISOs include CAISO (California Independent System Operator), PJM (PJM Interconnection), and MISO (Midcontinent Independent System Operator).
*   **Market Administrator:** The Market Administrator (MA) is responsible for designing and operating the wholesale electricity market. They set up the rules and mechanisms for trading and settling transactions. An example of a market administrator is the NYISO (New York Independent System Operator).
*   **Spot Market:** The spot market is where generators and loads buy and sell electricity on a real-time basis. This market is used to balance supply and demand in real-time.
*   **Day-Ahead Market:** The day-ahead market is a forward market where generators and loads agree on the amount of electricity to be traded for the next day. This market is used to plan for supply and demand.

    [Day-ahead Market Flowchart](https://i.imgur.com/6gZ1V1m.png)

*   **Bilateral Contracts:** Bilateral contracts are agreements between generators and loads to exchange electricity at a fixed price for a specified period of time. These contracts can be traded on an exchange or over-the-counter.

The dual settlement design of ISO power markets in the U.S. refers to the two-stage process used to determine the market clearing prices and payments for electricity traded on wholesale markets operated by Independent System Operators (ISOs) such as the PJM Interconnection, California ISO, New York ISO, etc.

Here are 7 key points about the dual settlement design:

* **Day-Ahead Market (DAM)**: The first stage is the Day-Ahead Market (DAM), where generators and load-serving entities submit their bids to purchase and sell electricity for the next day. The DAM price is determined by the clearing price that balances supply and demand.

* **Real-Time Market (RTM)**: The second stage is the Real-Time Market (RTM), which is an intra-day market that runs every 5-15 minutes to balance supply and demand in real-time. In the RTM, generators and loads submit bids to buy and sell electricity for the current hour. The RTM price is also determined by the clearing price that balances supply and demand.

![image2: RTM flow](https://www.pjm.com/-/media/production-sites/system-operational-visibility/rtm-flow-diagram.ashx)

* **Two-Stage Process**: The dual settlement design involves a two-stage process, where the DAM sets the base price and the RTM adjusts the price to reflect changes in real-time supply and demand.
* **Market Clearing Prices**: The dual settlement design determines market clearing prices for both the DAM and RTM, which are used to calculate payments to generators and payments from loads.
* **LMP**: In the RTM, the Locational Marginal Pricing (LMP) is used to determine the market clearing price, which varies by location on the grid.
* **Locational Marginal Pricing (LMP)**: LMP is a pricing method used in the RTM to reflect the value of electricity at each location on the grid. Generators and loads are paid or paid out based on the LMP at their location.
* **Settlement**: The dual settlement design is used to settle the transactions that occur in the DAM and RTM. The settlement process involves calculating the payments to generators and payments from loads based on the market clearing prices.

• **Financial Settlement**: 
The Settlement Administrator (SA) handles the financial aspects of electricity trade, calculating and paying for the energy that is actually delivered. The SA takes into account the physical flow of energy and the market prices that were in effect at the time of delivery.
